The main reason for success of the physical system model is their accuracy of measurements. Physical science, over the years developed many sophisticated measuring instruments with very high level of accuracy and precision. It is these instruments, that helped their mathematical models to predict the results with greater accuracy and verified at multiple research labs. This pearreview process forced the deficient models or theories to change or even completely thrown out.

Economist have a great challenge to improve its measurement capabilities. First, it uses parameters those are not physical and most conceptual. Secondly, the method of measurement the values of those parameters are too much error prone - survey, sample survey,...As a result, many economic theories, which should be in the dustbin of knowledge, are still in use and many economists practice those.

Economics will never be a science unless economist address this measurement issue.

Biology went through this transformation after the invention of double helix.

Big data can give the opportunity to change this - but standardization at international level is still big question mark. There is no institute like ISO for economics.

The definition of GDP, unemployment numbers ,... each country has its own way of defining them. It is a total anarchy - economic model results, garbage in and garbage out.

More nonsense. Wind speed is not the only factor that determines a storm's potential to do damage. Its size, the amount of moisture it carries and many other factors contribute as well — as they did when Hurricane Sandy hit.

The next generation of storms may not develop the wind speed of some storms of the past. But they will carry more water, on average, because there is more moisture in the atmosphere due to global warming. More water can translate to more flooding, which can be easily as destructive as super-fast winds, particularly if that flooding occurs over a wide-spread area or the rains continue for a long time.

This view of banks is dated. The era of "It's a Wonderful Life" is long over.

And by the way, it's true that a bank can't call in all its loans, but the Fed can help them in that situation.

First of all, stockholders are not owners - they are investors. Stock is equity financing for the corp. as opposed to debt financing with bond sales. Corporations can't be owned since they are autonomous bodies/persons in and of themselves in the legal sense. Otherwise, all the "owners" of the corp. would be personally liable for its acts and omissions, and "the stock would be dumped tomorrow", as you say. Just because the corps. want it both ways doesn't mean the law allows it - yet. Watch out all you actual human beings!

The whole idea of a bank is to borrow short-term through taking deposits or interbank loans, and make long-term loans at an interest rate priced to cover several types of risk, one of which is a run on the bank. A run can be survived, if it isn't systemic and the bank is transparently well-capitalized, by interbank borrowing.

FDIC protection was designed to protect depositors' capital (not banks) in case of a run. Besides paying premiums for the insurance, which attracts depositors, banks were required to borrow and lend soberly. That lowers bank profits, so they've found ways around the sober part.

I second Martin Weiss - set up a public bank for all consumer services and existing consumer debt, make the investment banks quit cold turkey, suffer their runs, and see who's left standing. Then start over with prudent regulation biased toward systemic stability, then sell the public bank to investors.

I agree. But there's a simple solution that doesn't require reinventing our entire economy. That solution is a Basic Income Grantee. It's just a simple and direct wealth redistribution system which is funded by those making the money, but distributed evenly to everyone. It allows the few, to be the produces, while allowing everyone, to take part in the consumption role of the economy. It's just welfare, but it's a very simple, and broad form of welfare that takes the government out of the role of making welfare decisions for the people.

The underlying current problem, is that technology is driving every rising levels of inequality as the value of human labor is steadily deprecated and replaced by machines. Inequality is created as the wealth flows to the owners of the tech (the few), and away from the workers (the many).

A basic income guarantee is the obvious and direct fix to this problem. Force some of the money (certainly not all of it), to flow away from the few, and back to the many.

Nothing else about our economy needs to be changed. Just add a tax and force the wealth to be better shared, and everything else fixes itself.

Ecology can predict that populations experiencing rapid growth are headed for a crash. Predicting when and how that crash will happen can demand more data and more accurate models than we have, but we know it is coming even without a lot of data.

Economics is in the same position. We know there will be bubbles in market economies. We also know that these bubbles will surprise most of the economic players, and that those who see them coming will try to make money from them rather than stopping them. Whoever stops a bubble must be outside the bubble; the referee cannot be a player.

To use these understandings for exact prediction, we need more data and finer models than we have now. Computers make these possible.

We also know that the understanding of economics affects how people behave and thus economics, and that often certain understandings of economics are used to advance or fight economic interests. This makes economics inherently more complex than other sciences, with feedback structures not found in physical science.

The thinking out of which economic models arise needs to be dialectical. If an investment is good, many people make it, and then it becomes a bad investment. The way to beat the market is to figure out what everyone else is going to do and do it first. Modeling these basic economic structures needs to reflect their dialectical nature, and economists do not read, say, Hegel, and how master and servant switch roles.

The problem with the drop-side cribs is that parents were not putting them together correctly. Such an incorrectly assembled crib could allow an infant or toddler to partially slip through the space between the mattress and the bottom of the drop-side, and then get strangled. A slight hardware adjustment fixes the drop-side so that it is just an ordinary immobile side. Whether a parent who could not assemble the crib correctly in the first place would be able to correctly install the modifying hardware is cause for concern.

I, for one, verified that the drop-side on my son's crib was installed correctly, and I felt completely comfortable using it.
